Very broad scale model with fine resolution; what would be the ecological meaning of the changes in functional composition and composition?

EBV name: Com abund of functional groups of soft-bottom macroinvertebrates
Step in identification process: Comments from participants of the EBV workflows- and WP4/WP5 showcases & co-design workshops
Observations: No ecological meaning!

EBV name: Com biomass of funct gr of terrestrial arthropods
Spatial resolution unit: Small territorial units for statistics (NUTS) from Eurostat (1166 regions at NUTS 3 level). Or 10x10km - 50x50km
Observations: No ecological meaning! It will have some meaning if a set of functional groups was predefined with a ecological question in the background, but no just measuring biomas of decomposers or predators. Abundance in number of individuals rather biomass could be more accurate; also ratios of abundances could be interesting to show variation in functionality (i.e. predators vs herbivores). Spatial resolution for NUTS have no ecological meaning; make no sense to measure biodiversity in political grids.

It measures composition and function becuse of measurements of soil respiration and biomass (microbes); It has no meaning to meaure in such broad resolution (soil assemblages have great variations at very fine scales).

EBV name: Com abund & taxonomic diversity of pollinator
Spatial resolution unit: Small territorial units for statistics (NUTS) from Eurostat (1166 regions at NUTS 3 level). Or 10x10km - 50x50km
Observations: Why does it say predicted number of individuals as the main metric if it is based in abundance from in situ measurements?? Doesnt seem realistic the high numer of sites >2000 if need to high taxonomic resolution (functional groups maybe make sense here)

When applying indicators such as BIOMASS we lose all fine details that may be very important for maintaining biodiversity. We wont have any taxonomic resolution for this, so it will be a very gross way to obtain data (interesting though for seing broad changes)
idem but for bats rather birds

Here I really doubt that we can have relevant information from radar data on insects. Maybe only for highly gregarious insects (langostas) that fly in big masses but not for gather any details on most of the insect biomass.
How the hell is this going to be measured? Edna? If this is the case what is the sampling design especially for specific sites?

Spatial resolution unit: Lakes as delineated in ECRINS (European catchments and rivers network system)
Temporal resolution unit: Real-time, weekly-monthly during the growing season
Observations: I like it. Cheap and easy because most algal blooms might be very similar in composition (same species). But maybe we will be losing information about changes on the composition of the bloom, just saying algal blooms without any differenciation. Maybe study a little of algal blooms to understand better
